ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My use of the Chinese language expanded greatly.
More Chinese vocabulary and grammar structure.
I improved my Chinese speaking and reading in this class the most.
I improved my Chinese speaking abilities.
Chinese learning skills
My vocabulary became stronger so did my reading and speaking skills

I improved my listening skills more than anything else in this language class.  I found myself understanding more and more of what my teacher said as the semester went on.  I also made some great friends in this seminar class, which is a testament to the bonding quality of the language class at Yale.
I got much more comfortable conversing in Chinese, became familiar with common grammatical structures, and also expanded my vocabulary.
Increasing my listening comprehension and speaking fluidity
More advanced knowledge of Chinese grammar, new words & constructions.
My proficiency in Chinese grew quite a bit from taking this course, especially conversationally.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is structured very well. My only complaint is the presentations on the chapter essays don't really help.
Not really a fan of any language course that I've taken at Yale. This one was no better or worse than any of the others.

I like the set up of this class, but I think that there should be flexibility with assignments. Given the frequency of meetings of this course, I think it should offer opportunities to excuse a few assignments.
It is very structured and it makes it easier to follow. I wish they were even smaller classes
Strength is that it focuses on speaking/reading as opposed to writing, and that the writing is all on the computer which allows for a faster pace of learning which is more applicable to real life.

I think this course could teach to the test a little more, or modify the test to fit more of what we cover in class.  The writing portion of our tests is very, very difficult, and I often felt underprepared for the section no matter how hard I studied.  I also felt that I didnt really know how to study for this portion, given most of what we do in class is speaking, listening, and grammar/sentence construction.

The four synchronous days plus on asynchronous day was a good balance, and I felt like the time during class was a good combination of lecture and conversation. I cant think of any particular weaknesses.
More writing in characters

Strengths: very organized, engaging, fun, prioritizes learning over grading, extremely qualified instructors
Weakness: the textbook is outdated

The powerpoint slides were helpful for learning new grammar and vocabulary, but I wish we did more engaging activities to change up the class structure sometimes. I think my two favorite classes of the semester were (1) when we had a debate and (2) when we did a job recruitment fair but speed-dating style. The asynchronous Fridays were a nice way to end the week and allowed us to talk to people we don't typically converse with in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it is structured very well and truly helps your Chinese.
Not unless you're taking it to fulfill a language requirement and are really set on Mandarin.
Yes! The Chinese department is amazing!
Yes, really progresses your Chinese learning from intermediate to being able to use it in real life.
Yes
Yes
Yes, I would. It was a comprehensive way to get better at a language and I could definitely feel myself improving.
If you want to learn an Asian language, definitely! This course is extremely organized, and can get you to good conversational ability quickly.

Seems to be a lot more work than many of the other L3 languages at Yale, but I think that is typical of the Chinese program for all levels here. The textbook was less comprehensive than the L1 and L2 textbook, but the exams were much simpler. It is not too difficult to get an A if you participate in class and keep up with the work.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student that is looking to keep progressing in learning Chinese. It is definitely a step above L1 and L2 Chinese with longer essays being assigned and more new characters to learn. However, the class is structured in a clear and effective way and I felt that I was learning a lot of useful Chinese.
